intro: Dicranopygium omichlophilum, commonly known as the narrow-leaf moss, is a species of moss belonging to the family Dicranaceae. It is characterized by its slender, often curved leaves that are typically less than 10 millimeters in length. The plant forms dense, cushion-like growths and is often found in moist, shaded environments such as forest floors or rocky areas. Its spore-producing structures, known as sporophytes, are relatively short and often embedded within the leafy shoots. Dicranopygium omichlophilum plays a role in soil stabilization and contributes to the ecological diversity of its habitat.
